title: Conductors - connecting spheres with equal sigma

content.question: Two positively-charged conducting spheres, <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>, have radii <math alttext="r sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>r</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></msub></math> and <math alttext="r sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>r</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></msub></math>, respectively, where <math alttext="r sub B is greater than r sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>r</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>r</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></msub></math>. The two spheres initially have the same uniform surface charge density and are located far apart so that their electric fields do not affect one another. Which of the following describes what will happen when a thin conducting wire is connected to both spheres and best explains why?

choices.label: Electrons will move from Sphere <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> to Sphere <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>. Sphere <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> is originally at a higher electric potential.

Electrons will move from Sphere <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> to Sphere <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>. Sphere <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> has a larger radius.

Electrons will move from Sphere <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> to Sphere <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>. Sphere <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> has less charge.

Electrons will move from Sphere <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> to Sphere <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>. Sphere <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> has a smaller radius.
